In chapter II » Spartan Territory under the Principate : ( i ) the Frontiers ; ( 2 ) the Economic Resources «,  we are given a detailed study of the frontiers of Spartan territory,  in which the evidence from the existing boundary - marks and the fragmentary delimitation - record from Messene are handled with commendable clarity and understanding,  all the more creditable seeing that the author has not,  apparently,  studied the terrain in detail herself.  ( The map,  at the end of the volume,  is helpful in this respect,  but curiously omits Amyclae and,  more curiously,  puts Sparta on the east bank of the Eurotas!  ) The account of the economic resources is a valuable collection of widely scattered evidence.  It might be suggested that the produce of the lead mines at Cardamyle continued to be of importance imder the Principate for building - purposes,  for,  to take an obvious example,  the total weight of the leaden clamps and dowels used for the marble Parodos - walls of the theatre at Sparta must have been very substantial.  The hunting of wild animals on Taygetus,  whether for the leather - industry or,  still more,  for the wild - beast trade for Roman venatiomSy is a picturesque addition to the economic background of Roman Sparta,  and may help to account for the undoubted wealth of some of its prominent families.
